awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Telehealth nasoendoscope for remote diagnosis and therapy of ear, nose, and throat disorders
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a lower-cost, improved performance nasoendoscope (nasal endoscope) system for diagnosis of ear, nose and throat conditions. There are three main types of endoscopes: rigid optical, fiberscope, and video-endoscope. Those which are cost effective for widespread use tend to lack adequate performance specifications and features. Presently, nasoendoscopes are often too cumbersome during the procedure and the documentation of results is time-consuming. Additionally, current nasoendoscopes are difficult and costly to disinfect. The proposed devise is user-friendly device and can help qualified medical personnel conduct diagnostic examinations of the nasal cavity and reach high-quality diagnoses more quickly. This proposed project explores implementation and commercialization opportunities in Otolaryngology markets as well as Sleep Medicine, Speech and Language Pathology, and veterinary markets. The innovation can have significant impact on patient care and safety, as well as reductions in long-term care costs and medical waste.

This I-Corps project develops a nasoendoscope utilizing Universal Serial Bus (USB) to power and stream video. The device is used by qualified medical personnel to visualize areas within the nasal cavity for diagnosis, tracking, and therapeutic biofeedback purposes. The novel nasoendoscope system includes software that allows the user to power the device, view, and share the video through a single cable, greatly simplifying the procedure and subsequent documentation. The design allows for real-time sharing of the procedure and seamless integration into a clinic's workflow. Previous progress on this project has focused on the theoretical development and experimental verification of the electrical design. This effort will be used to refine understanding of product-market fit and will further inform the development path and specification focus.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project was to conduct customer discovery interviews to identify needs within the Otolaryngology space. The final goal was to identify if there was an application for our medical imaging device designed at Stanford University. Prior to this grant, our team had developed a design for an affordable ?plug-and-play? nasal endoscope system. A nasal endoscope is a commonly used medical imaging device which can visualize the nasal cavity and be used to visually diagnose a variety of nasal conditions.

 

Through this grant, we conducted over 150 interviews with stakeholders involved in the treatment of chronic nasal obstruction (a condition that 35 million Americans face). Those interviews included physicians, patients, advanced practitioners, sterile processors, engineers, and investors. They were transcribed, coded, and analyzed. As we were in the middle of an international pandemic, most interviews were over video calls. During the final 3 months of the 12-month grant period, travel mandates were lifted, and we traveled to meet stakeholders in person including at 4 domestic industry events. We initially began with a focus on Otolaryngologists (Ear, Nose, and Throat specialists), but found a better application for our technology to meet the needs of primary care practitioners. User needs were consolidated, visualizations (including patient care maps and treatment algorithms) were created, and a small amount of prototyping was completed.

We found that there are over 35 million Americans who suffer from chronic nasal obstruction (a stuffed or blocked nose for 4 or more months), which can have a large impact on quality of life. We initially believed that these patients are mostly diagnosed and treated by Otolaryngologies (Ear, Nose, and Throat practitioners). However, there are only 10,000 Otolaryngologists (ENTs) in the USA. Most patients are diagnosed and treated by their primary care practitioners, often going through multiple rounds of failed treatments before being referred to a specialist if needed.

Nasal obstruction is the cardinal presenting symptom for a wide range of disease, from allergies to cancers. Primary care practitioners are tasked with distinguishing between etiology and determining effective (at times lifesaving) treatment. Visualization is the only way to make this determination. Primary care practitioners have only anterior rhinoscopy available to them, a tool which is widely considered inadequate for diagnosis.

Innovations in the Ear, Nose, and Throat space almost exclusively focus on the needs of Ear, Nose, and Throat specialists (ENTs, Otolaryngologists). However, there are only 10,000 active Otolaryngologists in the USA, and as a surgical specialty, they are in the operating room conducting a wide range of head, neck, throat, ear, and nose surgeries. Most of the 35 million nasal patients in the USA are diagnosed, treated, and medically managed by their primary care practitioner. Innovation in the ENT space needs to focus on this group of practitioners.

Our design for a novel nasal endoscope can have a great impact on patient care when designed for primary care practitioners rather than ENTs as initially intended.

We began working with the UCSF-Stanford FDA Pediatric Device Consortium, as well as numerous contract manufacturers to assemble a prototype design. We submitted this design as a provisional utility patent.


Last Modified: 02/02/2023
Modified by: Lambertus Hesselink
